articles.snippet: The survivors of California’s most destructive wildfire in history remain resilient in the meantime. But the meantime has no discernible end.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICO, Calif. — One evening, here in the college town of Chico, as I was pulling weeds from the vegetable beds in my front yard, I looked up to find an elderly woman watching me, her little dog tugging at her. “I miss my garden,” she hollered from the sidewalk. I nodded, after pausing, half-expecting her to say more. “I’m from Paradise,” she continued.
articles.abstract: The survivors of California’s most destructive wildfire in history remain resilient in the meantime. But the meantime has no discernible end.

headline.main: Don’t Forget About Paradise, or Those Beside It

articles.snippet: On a spectacular stretch of California coastline, vineyards, gorgeous beaches, markets and Mission-style architecture beckon.
articles.lead_paragraph: With its Mission-style facades and showy tropical foliage, Santa Barbara could be a commercial for the California good life. It can be easy to underestimate the struggles of a place so seemingly flawless. But Santa Barbara has had a tough few years. From the devastating wildfires in 2017 and 2018 to the flooding and mudslides that followed, the county has experienced more than its share of trauma. Yet if it weren’t for the charred chaparral faintly visible on the surrounding hillsides, the average visitor might never know. This is, after all, a place that’s good at reinventing itself. That spirit is on display at the new Hotel Californian, which sits on the site of a grand beach resort that was destroyed — just weeks after opening — by the 1925 earthquake that defined modern Santa Barbara’s architecture and character. Smack in the center of Southern California’s spectacular coastline, the county is surprisingly rural. In its multigenerational ranches and farms, its remarkably undeveloped public beaches, and the expansive Los Padres National Forest, Santa Barbara County offers glimpses of California before it got crowded.
articles.abstract: On a spectacular stretch of California coastline, vineyards, gorgeous beaches, markets and Mission-style architecture beckon.

headline.main: 36 Hours in Santa Barbara County
headline.print_headline: Santa Barbara County, Calif.

articles.snippet: The state faces enormous challenges to prevent the catastrophic wildfires of recent years.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — The New Normal is the phrase many use to describe the ways our world is evolving as the climate changes. As we have seen in recent years in the American West, and especially in California, it means dealing with more frequent and more devastating wildfires.
articles.abstract: The state faces enormous challenges to prevent the catastrophic wildfires of recent years.

headline.main: Turning Off the Lights in California

articles.snippet: It is easy to ignore climate change in the bosom of the developed world. But you can’t fail to notice when the lights go out.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the beginning of October, my kids’ preschool informed me that it might be closed the next day because of rolling blackouts — a radical new effort by our local power utility in Northern California to avoid sparking wildfires. The water company, faced with the shutdown of its pumps, asked us to fill our bathtubs before the cutoff. On the advice of experts, my car was backed into the driveway for a quick escape, its hatch packed with seven gallons of water and a go-bag including leather gloves, breathing masks, spare clothes, headlamps and emergency food.
articles.abstract: It is easy to ignore climate change in the bosom of the developed world. But you can’t fail to notice when the lights go out.

articles.snippet: For many California farmers, it means potentially losing everything.
articles.lead_paragraph: GUINDA, Calif. — Less than a year ago, while my husband and I were picking lettuce, a hot dry wind brought a cloud of smoke over my farm here in the Capay Valley. The wind didn’t die down, and neither did the smoke. For weeks afterward, we harvested produce while covered in the ashes of California’s most deadly wildfire. We cried for the dead, gave thanks for our own survival, and adjusted to a new California reality: Fire will always be knocking at our door.
articles.abstract: For many California farmers, it means potentially losing everything.

headline.main: What Does It Mean to Lose Power on a Farm?

articles.lead_paragraph: California residents hit a milestone in March: for the first time in eight years the state was officially out of a drought. That drought, atop years of record breaking temperatures, had helped spur the creation of enormous wildfires. Many wondered if 2019 would be a quieter wildfire season.

articles.snippet: As power is cut to reduce the wildfire risk from electrical wires and towers, a primary source of emergency communication is put in jeopardy.
articles.lead_paragraph: California’s recent power shut-offs, meant to reduce the risk of potentially catastrophic fires, have had an unwelcome side effect. The blackouts have also cut power to many cellphone towers, blocking the main communications source for many in harm’s way.

byline.original: By Carol Pogash and Brian X. Chen

articles.snippet: The New York Times would like to see photos and videos from people in California affected by wildfires up and down the state.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wildfires up and down the state of California are driving people from their homes. As of Monday, the Kincade fire, in the heart of Sonoma County, had consumed 66,000 acres and was only 5 percent contained. Gov. Gavin Newsom said that 880,000 people were without power in the state.

articles.abstract: Even after the state’s largest utilities shut off electricity to millions of residents, their equipment was still suspected of starting some fires.
articles.snippet: Even after the state’s largest utilities shut off electricity to millions of residents, their equipment was still suspected of starting some fires.
articles.lead_paragraph: As firefighters worked to contain wildfires across California on Saturday, residents began returning to their homes, business owners surveyed the damage and officials shifted their attention to what had gone wrong and what could be done to prevent — or at least temper — what has become a near-constant threat.

headline.main: As Smoke Clears in California, Pressure Builds on Power Companies
headline.print_headline: California Power Companies Manage Growing Anger

articles.abstract: Medical evacuees are the new refugees of climate change.
articles.snippet: Medical evacuees are the new refugees of climate change.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — I must have missed the wildfire evacuation course in medical school. Learning how to move critically ill patients while flames lick the ground just feet away wasn’t part of my residency training. Most physicians never anticipate having to empty their hospitals while smoke fills the halls and the sky glows red.

headline.main: When ‘Do No Harm’ Means Evacuating Hospitals in California
headline.print_headline: Can Hospitals Survive the Flames?

articles.abstract: In a letter to state regulators, the local leaders proposed using their collective resources to take over the utility, now in bankruptcy.

articles.lead_paragraph: Frustrated with wildfires and intentional blackouts caused by Pacific Gas & Electric, more than two dozen California mayors and county leaders are calling for a customer-owned power company to replace the giant utility.

headline.print_headline: Invasive Grasses May Worsen Wildfires, Study Suggests

articles.abstract: For residents of Sonoma County, Calif., the threat of wildfire is the new reality.
articles.snippet: For residents of Sonoma County, Calif., the threat of wildfire is the new reality.
articles.lead_paragraph: From the safe remove of a faraway place, the devastation and fear that have accompanied California’s wildfires can be hard to grasp. The numbers — over a dozen separate fires across the state and hundreds of thousands of people displaced — are shocking, and the tales of flames and smoke engulfing neighborhood hillsides are disturbing. But what is the new normal in California has little in common with the reality of many of our everyday lives. And so we go on. We think of friends and relatives, maybe send a text to touch base with them. Then refill our coffee cups. Read our email. Click through to the next article.

headline.main: Living With the Kincade Fire

byline.original: By Philip Montgomery and Clinton Cargill

articles.lead_paragraph: The fires that raged in California over the past two weeks consumed thousands of acres and drove residents up and down the state to flee their homes.

headline.main: 5 Lessons We Learned From the California Wildfires
headline.print_headline: 5 Lessons Learned at the Midpoint of the California Wildfire Season

byline.original: By Tim Arango, Jose A. Del Real and Ivan Penn

articles.abstract: I spent five days last year fighting the California wildfires in Malibu. It felt like the combat patrols I had been on as a Marine in Afghanistan.
articles.snippet: I spent five days last year fighting the California wildfires in Malibu. It felt like the combat patrols I had been on as a Marine in Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: In boot camp, I was surprised by the pride the other recruits took in their no-name Midwest hometowns. By contrast, I had no love for Malibu, Calif., which seemed like only one thing to me: an isolated beach town too far from the city for me to escape. I did not surf. I had no luck with girls. Years before I was old enough to enlist, the Sept. 11 attacks gave me a sure direction away from a dysfunctional home: I was determined to join the Marine Corps. So I spent my youth running Malibu’s hills, swimming its coast, avoiding a home that smelled of stale white wine and counting the days until I could enlist in the military. But my antipathy toward Malibu did nothing to stem a stream of brotherly abuse from the other recruits for what they perceived as my star-studded hometown. Their idea of Malibu was very different from what my reality had been.

headline.main: My Neighborhood Was on Fire. My Neighbors Came Together to Save It.

articles.abstract: California’s largest utility needs to reach a settlement with victims of wildfires and other creditors while fending off calls for a state takeover.
articles.snippet: California’s largest utility needs to reach a settlement with victims of wildfires and other creditors while fending off calls for a state takeover.
articles.lead_paragraph: After an autumn marked by mass blackouts and wildfires, Pacific Gas & Electric is racing to craft a plan to escape bankruptcy. That plan needs to satisfy fire victims and state officials who are threatening to take over PG&E, California’s largest utility, unless executives improve its safety record.

headline.main: PG&E Struggles to Find a Way Out of Bankruptcy
headline.print_headline: PG&E Scrambles for a Way Out of Bankruptcy

byline.original: By Lauren Hepler, Peter Eavis and Ivan Penn

articles.abstract: As climate change pushes California’s fire season into Australia’s, an intricate system of resource sharing struggles with the load.
articles.snippet: As climate change pushes California’s fire season into Australia’s, an intricate system of resource sharing struggles with the load.
articles.lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Sharing the giant air tankers that fight fires 5,000 gallons of water at a time used to be simpler. California’s wildfires faded before Australia’s bush fires surged, leaving time to prepare, move and deploy planes from one continent to another.

headline.main: The World Burns All Year. Are There Enough Planes to Douse the Flames?
headline.print_headline: Climate Change Puts Strain on World’s Ability to Douse the Flames

articles.abstract: A California commission’s findings in the state’s deadliest fire could make a path out of bankruptcy and probation much harder.
articles.snippet: A California commission’s findings in the state’s deadliest fire could make a path out of bankruptcy and probation much harder.
articles.lead_paragraph: A damning report about the cause of the deadliest wildfire in California history poses a huge setback to Pacific Gas & Electric as it tries to resolve a complex bankruptcy and prove to its customers and elected officials that it takes safety seriously.

headline.main: Report Detailing PG&E’s Failures Raises New Hurdles for Utility
headline.print_headline: Utility’s Future More Uncertain After Scathing Report on Fire

articles.abstract: The state's unusual  decision  exposes the insurance industry’s miscalculation of the cost of climate change.

articles.lead_paragraph: California’s wildfires have grown so costly and damaging that insurance companies — a homeowner’s last hope when disaster strikes — have increasingly been canceling people’s policies in fire-prone parts of the state.

headline.main: California Bans Insurers From Dropping Policies Made Riskier by Climate Change

articles.abstract: The utility has faced objections from the governor of California and hedge funds vying for control of the company.

articles.lead_paragraph: Pacific Gas & Electric reached a $1.7 billion settlement with California regulators for deadly wildfires started by its equipment in 2017 and 2018, resolving one of several obstacles facing the company, which sought bankruptcy protection in January.
